awd_titl_txt: Chemical Tools for Understanding Histidine Phosphatase Activity
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Amy Barrios at the University of Utah to study the newly discovered protein histidine phosphatase family of enzymes. Communication between and within cells is critical in controlling all aspects of cellular activity, including cell growth, cell division, and cell death. One common way that cells communicate signals is by chemically changing proteins by adding or removing a phosphate group. The Barrios research group develops chemical tools that can be used to study the enzymes responsible for removing phosphate groups from proteins, providing insights into cellular mechanisms of communication. This project focuses on the newly discovered family of histidine phosphatase enzymes. The chemical tools being developed in this project have the potential to provide valuable insight into the roles played by these enzymes in cellular signaling and thus, provide fundamental insights into this poorly studied, but critically important, mode of cellular signaling. Key to the success of the project is the inclusion of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers from diverse backgrounds with the goal of broadening participation in research. In addition, Dr. Barrios is committed to mentoring junior scientists and is working to create a university-wide framework to provide support and career development opportunities for postdoctoral researchers. 

Reversible protein phosphorylation is widely used in biology to regulate protein-protein interactions and cellular signaling pathways. While phosphorylation at serine, threonine and tyrosine in mammalian cells is widely recognized as critical, histidine phosphorylation is much less well understood. Recently, three mammalian histidine phosphatases have been discovered. These enzymes play critical roles in regulating ion channels, T-cell receptor signaling, and G-protein coupled receptor signaling, with additional, yet-undiscovered roles likely. Researchers in the Barrios lab are developing chemical probes that will facilitate monitoring the activity of individual histidine phosphatases both in vitro and in cells. Specifically, the Barrios lab is developing selective substrates and inhibitors of histidine phosphatase activity that can be used to address key questions about histidine phosphatase biology. This approach can readily be applied to almost any member of the histidine phosphatase family of enzymes. The research objectives are integrated with work aimed at broadening participation in science by engaging undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers from diverse backgrounds and with efforts to enhance the framework for postdoctoral training through the development of programs that support early-career scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Summary and Outcomes Reversible protein phosphorylation is widely used in biology to regulate protein-protein interactions, cellular signaling pathways, etc. While phosphorylation at serine, threonine, and tyrosine amino acids in mammalian cells is widely recognized as critical, phosphorylation of the amino acid histidine is much less well understood. A handful of enzymes responsible for phosphorylating and dephosphorylating histidine in mammalian cells have been identified. This modification is believed to play critical roles in regulating ion channels, T-cell receptor signaling, and G-protein coupled receptor signaling, with other, yet-undiscovered roles likely. In this project, we developed a toolkit of chemical approaches for studying the biological roles of histidine phosphorylation. We focused on measuring and manipulating the activity of the key histidine phosphatase enzyme PHPT1. We have validated a series of fluorogenic substrates that can be used to visualize the activity of PHPT1. We have identified the first inhibitors of PHPT1 activity and have assembled a panel of several different chemical scaffolds that inhibit PHPT1 activity. Finally, we have been investigating both the biological impact of histidine phosphorylation and the biological regulation of histidine phosphorylation. Specifically, we have discovered that phosphorylation on a specific tyrosine residue of PHPT1 (tyrosine 93) results in a complete inhibition of PHPT1 activity. The chemical tools in this work can be applied to almost any member of the histidine phosphatase family of enzymes.

In this funding period, we accomplished all our objectives. We have developed novel fluorogenic substrates as reporters of histidine phosphatase activity (Objective 1), investigated libraries of peptides as histidine phosphatase substrates and inhibitors to learn more about the substrate selectivity (Objective 2), tested some of these lead compounds in a cellular environment (Objective 3), and learned that tyrosine phosphorylation inhibits histidine phosphatase activity (Objective 4). Some of our results have been published already and we are in the process of preparing additional manuscripts for publication based on our work.

Intellectual Merit Our work on this project addressed a significant unmet need in the scientific community. We developed the first potent and selective chemical probes for addressing the roles of histidine phosphatase enzymes in cellular signaling. Our discoveries provide the scientific community with the chemical tools needed to better understand the biological roles of mammalian histidine phosphorylation.

Broader Impacts Through the inclusion of high school students from the local area and undergraduate students from the University of Utah in our research activities, the broader impacts of the work have been significant. My research group participated in outreach programs to the local community, including spending time sharing their science with youth in custody through STEMCAP (STEM Community Alliance Program). Through my work as Associate Dean for Postdoctoral Affairs on campus, I have created a career development workshop series for postdocs across campus that is offered on an annual basis.


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Amy M Barrios
